page.title: 03GEOLOGY cont...
page.content:
The{Jurassic}sea submerged the area during{Lias}times, depositing a beach conglomerate (Chilcote Stone, used in the construction of Wells Cathedral) followed by deep water muds (Lias clays and mudstones). These {horizontal beds rest unconformably on {the older rocks}and now{outcrop}along the l30-metre contour.
During the{glacial phases of the {Pleistocene,}the weaker Lias Clays and Red Marls were re-excavated by {meltwater streams to form}the present day{Chilcote and Sheppey Valleys. Both are deeply incised and fed by distinctive{combes}which are now{dry {valleys}(e.g. Middleway Wood and Ham Woods). The upland drainage is now underground and feeds St. Andrew's Well springs by the Cathedral.
